column4: Anyone have any problems with devices no longer being recognized?
it sounds like a module issue.. what has changed on your system?
I'm running 64 bit ubuntu.. it runs great (with the exception of the atheros driver)
Syslog showed that it was there, recognnized, but /dev didn't show it
did they show up using lsmod?
Let me check
what device did you lose?
any that were plugged in, such as sda and sdb
are these SATA or scsi devices?
well, _technically_ not SCSI, but I heard from somewhere that sd* would be that
these are probably USB storage devices.. are they USB plug-ins?
Excuse me?
are these little usb sticks?
yes
then use: lsmod | grep usb
usb_storage should be shown as loaded
what output do you want?
it's there
usb_storage            74304  0
that means device is not connected..
well, there are two devices connected
check dmesg when you unplug and replug the usb stick
aight
[17192568.604000]  usb 4-8: USB disconnect, address 16
disconnect...
nothing on connect
try: modprobe usb_storage
nothing returned
use: depmod -a, then modprobe usb_storage
done, but no results still
GNU/Linux
what brand of USB storage is it?
any USB device I plug in, iPod, sandisk cruzer, etc.
all I did was run shred on my flash drive, then fdisked it, and then mkdosfs
I had missing superblock errors, then everything went downhill
udev too
let me check and I'll be back
Have you tried rebooting the box to see if it made a difference?
that usually fixes the problem
found this in syslog
Dec 31 17:17:38 localhost kernel: [17188908.920000]  usb-storage: device scan complete
Dec 31 17:18:31 localhost kernel: [17188962.000000]   10:0:0:0: rejecting I/O to dead device
Dec 31 17:18:31 localhost kernel: [17188962.000000]  FAT: bread failed in fat_clusters_flush
well.. if the linux kernel does not find a valid media then it will ignore it.. and this is probably what happend.
however, when this happenedDec 31 17:47:32 localhost kernel: [17190703.156000]  sd 13:0:0:0: Attached scsi removable disk sda
it was still  not working
nothing in /dev
however, using mknod sda1 b 8 1, then mounting, it worked
Ubuntu usually creates a mounting entry under /media.. did it create one?
no
a reboot should take care of all this - I just want to know what the problem is so I can avoid it in the future
thanks
good luck..
